p: The case studies we presented provided examples of how DDRP models may be parameterized and then run to produce various outputs including gridded and graphical predictions of the number of generations, life stages present, dates of phenological events, and areas of climatic suitability based on two levels of climate stress. We encourage users of DDRP to consider the limitations of the platform, to report the conditions that their model was designed to work under (e.g. a particular region, life stage event, or generation), and to document any known sources of model error that could not be accounted for when providing validation and other feedback reports. Additionally, models should be validated whenever possible, as we did for the E. postvittana and N. elegantalis models presented in this study. The flexible and open-source nature of DDRP will facilitate making modifications and improvements, such as adding new environmental factors, using it for other regions besides CONUS, modeling non-insect organisms, expanding the types of model products, and adding features to improve model accuracy.
